On ICMA's 2009 State of the Profession survey we asked: "Were citizens involved in decision making related to the fiscal crisis, such as decisions about how to allocate resources?" I have attached a file with the local governments in Massachusetts that said "yes." I hope this is helpful.
Best,

answers.author: Cheryl Hilvert
answers.text:
Hi Bryan!  Both Tim and Evelina have referred you to two good sources of information on the engagement of citizens in the budgeting process.  I would also suggest that you contact the Center for Priority Based Budgeting , which uses a performance based budgeting process that can incorporate public participation.  I know that CPBB did such a project in the City of Cincinnati with a public engagement element.   You can find more information and contacts on the Center for Priority Based Budgeting at   http://icma.org/en/results/management_strategies/leading_practices/priority-based_budgeting       You could also contact Lea Erikson, Budget Director at the City of Cincinnati to learn more about their process.

author: Bryan Smith
text:
My name is Bryan and I am a graduate student working on my final project.  
For this project, I am interested in the equity and sustainability aspects of using citizen engagement in the municipal budget and priority setting process.  While I have found a fair amount of literature on the topic, I am having trouble identifying community survey data that may help identify which communities use a formalized citizen involved process.  Geographically, I want to focus my project on municipalities of a single state.  My intention is to focus on Massachusetts.   Does this data exist?
I would appreciate any suggestions you may have.  Thank you for your time.
title: Does data exist on the use of citizen participation in municipal budgeting exist?
